questions.text: A preterm neonate admitted to NICU who received supplemental oxygen is being screened for retinopathy of prematurity. Fundus examination reveals a subtotal retinal detachment. How will you stage the disease?
questions.solution:
Subtotal retinal detachment is considered to be stage 4 of retinopathy of prematurity (ROP). 

The clinical staging of ROP is as follows:

  • Stage 1 - Formation of a demarcation line at the edge of vessels, dividing the vascular from the avascular retina.
  • Stage 2- Formation of an intraretinal ridge 
  • Stage 3- Ridge with extraretinal fibrovascular proliferation into the vitreous
  • Stage 4- Subtotal retinal detachment
  • Stage 5- Total retinal detachment

questions.text: An 8-year-old child from a rural slum area is brought to your OPD with deformity as shown in the image. Which of the following conditions is characteristically associated with this deformity?
questions.solution:
Windswept deformity (combination of valgus deformity of one leg with varus deformity of the other leg) is seen in rickets. It is also seen in rheumatoid arthritis but characteristically seen in rickets.

Other deformities of extremities seen in rickets:

  • Enlargement of wrists and ankles
  • Valgus or varus deformities of limbs
  • Anterior bowing of the tibia and femur
  • Coxa vara

questions.text: A 25-year-old male with Marfanoid features presented with sudden onset breathlessness. The chest X-ray is given below. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The chest X-ray demonstrating tracheal deviation and displacement of the heart away from the affected side along with the partial collapse of the left lung in the above condition points to a diagnosis of left-sided pneumothorax. 

Marfan's syndrome is one of the causes for seconday spontaneous pneumothorax in adults. 

Pneumothorax refers to the collection of air in the pleural space. 

Chest radiograph in spontaneous pneumothorax demonstrates:  

  • Thin, sharp white line, demarcating the visceral pleural edge
  • Absence of lung markings seen peripheral to this line
  • Peripheral space radiolucent compared to adjacent lung 
  • Complete lung collapse, as well as subcutaneous emphysema and pneumomediastinum, may be seen
  • Deep sulcus sign (on supine chest radiograph)

Deep sulcus sign: On a supine position(common in the ICU), air collects anteriorly and basally, within the non-dependent portions of the pleural space, abnormally deepening the costophrenic angle. This sign is indicative of pneumothorax in such patients and may be the only visible clue, especially when patient can not be imaged upright.

The image below is plain chest x-ray showing pneumothorax with deep sulcus sign (shown by arrow):

When there is a progressive accumulation of air intrapleurally in the thoracic cavity (caused by a valve effect during inspiration and expiration), it is called Tension pneumothorax. It can result in compression of mediastinal structures and compromise cardiopulmonary function. It is life-threatening and requires emergency intervention.

questions.text: A patient presents to the clinic for a change of her presbyopic glasses. This is the third time that she is coming in 2 months. What is the likely underlying diagnosis in this patient?
questions.solution:
Frequent changes in presbyopic glasses in this patient is a symptom of open-angle glaucoma (OAG).

This is due to increasing accommodative failure as a result of constant pressure on the ciliary muscle and nerve supply.

In intumescent cataracts, patients report difficulty with distance vision and frequent change of spectacle prescription. However, it is not associated with frequent changes of presbyopic glasses.

questions.text: A man is convicted for the offense of rape. Which section of the BNS lays down punishment for the same?
questions.solution:
Section 64 of the BNS (IPC 376) lays down the punishment for the offense of rape.  

Section 64 (1) of the BNS outlines the punishment for rape and section 64 (2) outlines the punishment for rape in custody/rape by a person in a position of authority or trust.

Section 63 of the BNS (IPC 375) outlines the definition of rape.

Section 72 of the BNS (IPC 228A) deals with the disclosure of a rape victim's identity.

Section 75 of the BNS (IPC 354A) deals with sexual harassment.

questions.text: What is the causative organism of angular conjunctivitis?
questions.solution:
Moraxella species, a type of gram-negative diplobacilli, are involved in causing angular conjunctivitis which is a type of chronic conjunctivitis.

Angular conjunctivitis is a chronic type of conjunctivitis where there is inflammation of the conjunctiva at the lid margins and the inner and outer canthi of the eyes with red, scaly, excoriated, macerated and fissured skin at the canthi. This is because of the proteolytic enzymes secreted by the Moraxella species.

Patients with angular conjunctivitis usually experience eye irritation, a burning sensation and collection of dirty-white, foamy discharge at the angles. These patients can also have associated blepharitis and papillary and follicular conjunctivitis.

Causative organisms are Moraxella lacunata, Moraxella axenfeld and Staphylococcus aureus (Rare cause). The source of infection is typically the nasal tract or the nasal discharge of patients with angular conjunctivitis. The infection spreads from the nasal cavity to the eyes through contaminated hands or handkerchiefs. Treatment includes oxytetracycline 1% ointment for 10 to 14 days, and zinc oxide as it inhibits proteolytic enzymes.

The image given below shows the eye of a patient infected with angular conjunctivitis.

Other options: 

Option B: Haemophilus influenzae causes acute conjunctivitis.

Option C: Adenovirus is the most common cause of viral conjunctivitis and it most commonly causes follicular conjunctivitis, pharyngoconjunctival fever, and epidemic keratoconjunctivitis.

Option D: Coxsackie B virus is known to cause aseptic meningitis, encephalitis, pericarditis, and myocarditis. There are no known mentions of ocular disease caused by the virus.

Note: Pathogens that cause bacterial conjunctivitis

Hyperacute (symptoms develop within 24 hours; aggressive course) Acute (resolving in less than 4 weeks)  Chronic (of greater than 4 weeks duration)
Neisseria gonorrhoeae Staphylococcus aureus Staphylococcus aureus
Neisseria meningitidis Streptococcus pneumoniae Moraxella lacunata
  Haemophilus influenzae Enteric bacteria

questions.text: Why is the TCA cycle called as an amphibolic pathway?

choices.text: Both oxidative and synthetic reactions take place
Metabolites are utilized in other pathways
It can proceed both in forward and backward direction
Same enzymes can be used in reverse direction

questions.solution:
In the TCA cycle, both oxidative and synthetic reactions take place.

The TCA cycle is not only a pathway for oxidation but also that of interconversion of metabolites arising from the transamination and deamination of amino acids. It provides the substrates for amino acid synthesis by transamination as well as for gluconeogenesis and fatty acid synthesis.

questions.text: In a patient with critical limb ischemia, what is the ankle-brachial pressure index (ABPI) likely to be?
questions.solution:
In a patient with critical limb ischemia, the ABPI is < 0.4.

Related Pearl: Ankle–brachial Pressure Index (ABPI)

The ankle-brachial Pressure Index (ABPI) is the ratio of systolic pressure at the ankle to that in the arm.

The numerator is the highest pressure in the dorsalis pedis, posterior tibial, or peroneal artery and the denominator is the highest brachial systolic pressure.

ABPI Reading Interpretation
>0.9 to <1.4 Normal
<0.9 Diagnostic of occlusive arterial disease in patients with symptoms of claudication or other signs of ischemia
0.5 to 0.9 Arterial obstruction often associated with claudication
<0.4 Critical limb ischemia (multilevel obstruction i.e any combination of iliac, femoral or tibial vessel disease and may be associated with non-healing ulcerations, ischemic rest pain, or pedal gangrene.
>1.4 Signifies poor compressibility of the arteries. Mostly due to calcification because of increased age, diabetes etc.

Note: A fall in the resting ABPI of more than 20% after exercise is indicative of arterial disease.

questions.text:
Non-oliguric renal failure may be seen in patients with which of the following conditions?
  1. Congestive heart failure 
  2. Aminoglycoside toxicity
  3. Contrast-induced nephropathy
  4. Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  5. Acute interstitial nephritis
questions.solution:
Non-oliguric renal failure may be seen in the following conditions:

  • Acute interstitial nephritis
  • Acute tubular necrosis (aminoglycoside toxicity, contrast-induced nephropathy)

All the causes of acute tubular necrosis (ATN) cause non-oliguric AKI except acyclovir (oliguric AKI).

The difference in urine output between oliguric and non-oliguric AKI may be due to variations in GFR or in the rate of tubular reabsorption. Non-oliguric forms may be associated with less severe injury.

Other options: Prerenal causes such as congestive heart failure cause oliguric AKI. In post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis, oliguria occurs as a result of decreased GFR.

questions.text: True about methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is

choices.text: It is mediated by mecA gene
Polymerase chain reaction (PCR) is of no use in diagnosis
Cephalosporins are the drug of choice
Panton-Valentine toxin is associated with HA-MRSA (hospital acquired MRSA)

questions.solution:
Resistance in methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus is mediated by mecA gene, which is chromosomally coded.

  • It alters penicillin-binding protein (PBP) present on S. aureus cell wall to PBP-2a, which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.
  • Panton-valentine toxin is associated with CA-MRSA (community-acquired MRSA)
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice (should be used only if there is resistance to other drugs).
  • Drug of choice for nasal carriers of MRSA: mupirocin 2% ointment.

Related Pearl: Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)

MRSA Definition: Methicillin MIC 8 μg/ml or more, Oxacillin MIC 4 μg/ml or more.

Resistance in MRSA is mediated by mecA gene which is chromosomally coded. It alters PBP (penicillin-binding protein) present on S.aureus cell wall to PBP-2a which has less affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics.

Penicillin Binding Protein:

  • Normal protein present in all bacterial cell wall.
  • Transpeptidase in nature.
  • Required for cross-linking of the peptidoglycan layer (essential for cell wall synthesis).
  • It is also the site of attachment for- beta-lactam drugs to bind & inhibit.

Types of MRSA:

  • Community-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype IV and Possess PV Toxin(Panton-Valentine Toxin), monodrug resistance,more virulent
  • Hospital-acquired - mediated by mec A subtype I, II, III, multidrug resistance,less virulent.

Detection of MRSA:

  • Antibiotic susceptibility test on Muller Hilton agar (Disk diffusion test) by using Methicillin or Oxacillin disc or cefoxitin disc.
  • PCR for detection of mecA gene.

Treatment:

  • Vancomycin is Drug Of Choice (should be used only if other drugs are resistant ).
  • Others- Teicoplanin, Linezolid, streptogramin, cipro/levofloxacin, cotrimoxazole, clindamycin, mupirocin, minocycline.
  • Newer Drugs – Daptomycin, ceftobiprole, tigecycline, oritavancin, dalbavancin, telavancin, delafloxacin.
  • Ceftobiprole and ceftaroline are 5th generation β lactams effective against MRSA.

questions.text: Which of the following stains is not used in the detection of calcium in tissues?
questions.solution:
The Congo red stain is used for staining amyloid bodies, not calcium.

The following staining techniques are used for calcium:

  • Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) -
    • Calcium forms a blue-black lake with hematoxylin 
  • Azan stain -
    • Used to distinguish osteoid from the mineralized bone
  • Alizarin red S stain -
    • Forms an orange-red lake with calcium
    • Works best with small amounts of calcium
    • An example is Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, seen in malakoplakia
  • Von Kossa method - 
    • Useful for tissues containing large amounts of phosphates and carbonates, such as bone
    • Silver ions react with phosphate in the presence of acidic material
    • Silver phosphate gets degraded to silver in presence of light, giving black color
    • MG bodies also stain with von kossa stain.

The image given below demonstrates MG bodies which are seen in malakoplakia using the Von Kossa stain.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding succinylcholine?

choices.text: It produces both phase I and phase II block
Precurarization reduces fasciculations and myalgia associated with Sch
It is a non–depolarizing muscle relaxant

questions.solution:
Succinylcholine is a depolarizing muscle relaxant.

Option A: It produces both phase I and phase II block (at a higher dose).

Option B: Succinylcholine can produce a rise in intracranial pressure as a result of increased cerebral blood flow due to muscle fasciculations.

Option C: Precurarization is the administration of a small dose of a non-depolarizing neuromuscular blocking agent, a few minutes before Sch to minimize complications like fasciculations, post-operative myalgia, rise in intragastric pressure, and rise in ICP.

Related Pearl: Types of muscle relaxants

There are 2 types of muscle relaxants: depolarizing and non-depolarizing.

Depolarizing Muscle Relaxant- Succinylcholine

Non-Depolarizing Muscle Relaxants:

  • Ultra short-acting (<10 minutes) - Gantacurium
  • Short-acting (10-20 minutes) - Mivacurium
  • Intermediate-acting (20-50 minutes)
    • Atracurium
    • Cisatracurium
    • Vecuronium
    • Rocuronium
  • Long-acting (>50 minutes)
    • Pancuronium
    • Doxacurium
    • Pipecuronium

questions.text: A 32 year old female patient with PCOS is worried that her hairline has shifted upwards exposing more of her forehead as shown below. Which of the following is incorrect about this type of hair loss and its treatment?

choices.text: DHT(dihydrotestosterone) is responsible for follicular regression
Arao-Perkins bodies are seen within the follicular stelae
Finasteride is the first line treatment

questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of male pattern androgenetic alopecia. Finasteride is not the first line treatment in women. 

Finasteride use in pregnancy can lead to teratogenic effects on male fetuses.

Androgenetic alopecia is a disorder characterized by a reduction of hair fiber production by follicles and miniaturization. It is of two types , male pattern and female pattern hair loss. Male pattern hair loss may occur in female & vice versa is also true. Male pattern hair loss causes frontal hairline recession and thinning of the vertex.

Miniaturization refers to a reduction in the size of follicles until it leaves behind a remnant called stelae or streamers. Elastic staining of the stelae shows Arao-Perkin's bodies.

DHT is a more potent form of testosterone. It is responsible for follicular regression and thus causes androgenic alopecia. Finasteride inhibits the enzyme that converts testosterone to DHT and hence is used for treatment.

Minoxidil is a potent vasodilator. It is used orally to treat severe hypertension. When used as a hair lotion, it prolongs the anagen phase and slows down or prevents hair loss. Drugs used to treat male pattern baldness:
  • Minoxidil lotion
  • 5-alpha reductase antagonist - Finasteride
Drugs used to treat female pattern baldness:
  • Minoxidil lotion
  • Anti-androgens - spironolactone, flutamide, and cyproterone acetate

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with a history of low back pain for the past 6 months. 2 years back, he was diagnosed with carcinoma of the prostate. His X-Ray has been shown below. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The question describes a history of prostate carcinoma. The prostate produces osteoblastic metastases and hence one can appreciate the sclerotic appearance on the radiogram.

Ankylosing spondylitis presents with a bamboo spine appearance.

The (absent) pedicle sign, also called the winking owl sign, occurs on plain film when a pedicle is absent.

The term, winking owl sign, where the missing pedicle corresponds to the closed eye, the contralateral pedicle to the other open eye, and the spinous process to the beak of the owl on AP views of the thoracic or lumbar spine. This most commonly indicates metastases.

questions.text:
In a village having a population of 5000, a diagnostic test for a particular disease showed the following results. What is the prevalence of the disease?
  Disease present Disease absent
Test positive 1000 50
Test negative 500 3450
Total 1500 3500
questions.solution:
Prevalence is given by the formula: 

In this scenario, the number of cases: 1000+500 = 1500.

Total population: 5000

Prevalence= 1500/5000 × 100 = 30%.

Related Pearl: Incidence and Prevalence

  • Incidence in Epidemiology:

Incidence is the number of new cases occurring in a defined population during a period of time. The incidence rate is expressed in person-time units, usually per 1000 per year. It is given by the following formula:

It is generally used for acute illnesses. It provides insight into the effectiveness of health services and programs. Incidence can be determined from cohort studies and longitudinal studies.

The incidence rate of spells of sickness =  (Number of spells of sickness starting in the specified period/Mean number of people exposed to that risk in the specified time) x 1000.

Special types of incidence rates:

1. Attack rate: It is used when there is a risk for a limited period of time.

2. Secondary attack rate: It is the number of exposed persons developing the disease within the range of incubation period following exposure to a primary case.

  • Prevalence in Epidemiology:

Prevalence is the proportion of all cases, old and new, of a particular disease at a given point in time or over a period of time in a given population. It is a proportion, not a rate or ratio. Prevalence is always expressed in percentage.

It is given by the formula:

It is useful to determine the magnitude of health problems. It can be determined from cross-sectional studies.

Types:

1. Point prevalence is the prevalence at a point in time. Usually, prevalence is point prevalence unless otherwise specified.

2. Period prevalence is the prevalence over a period of time.

Relationship between Incidence and Prevalence:

Prevalence depends upon incidence and duration.

Prevalence = Incidence x Mean Duration

Longer the duration of the disease, the greater the prevalence.

Few examples:

  • In acute diseases, because of rapid recovery/death prevalence will be relatively lower than incidence. This is because, in some diseases (eg. food poisoning), the disease is so short-lived, there are no "old cases".
  • In chronic diseases like TB, prevalence will be higher than incidence.
  • If a new treatment for a disease is effective, incidence does not change but prevalence decreases as the duration of disease decreases.
  • If the treatment only prevents death but doesn’t cure the disease, it may cause a paradoxical increase in prevalence.

questions.text: What are prevalence studies also known as?
questions.solution:
Cross-sectional studies help in obtaining the prevalence of a disease. Hence, they are also known as prevalence studies.

Cross-sectional study is a type of observational study where a cross-section of a population is examined once at one point in time. It is more useful in studying chronic diseases than acute ones. They do not provide information on the natural history of disease or incidence and also do not establish the time sequence.

questions.text: A 26-year-old batsman was rushed to the ER when he fell unconscious after a cricket ball hit his head. He regained consciousness later but started to deteriorate rapidly. A plain CT of the patient is shown below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The presence of lucid interval in this patient and the CT image are suggestive of extradural hematoma. The above CT scan shows a large extradural hematoma (hyperdense biconvex/lentiform shape) with a mass effect.

Extradural hemorrhage (EDH) is the accumulation of blood between the skull and the dura. It usually results from arterial disruption, especially of the middle meningeal artery. It lies behind the pterion, which is the thinnest part of the skull. 

In EDH, the patient is initially unconscious from the concussive aspect of the head trauma. The patient then awakens and has a “lucid interval,” while the hematoma sub-clinically expands. As the volume of the hematoma grows, intracranial pressure (ICP) increases, and the patient rapidly becomes lethargic and herniates.

Uncal herniation from an EDH classically causes ipsilateral third nerve palsy and contralateral hemiparesis.

Related Pearl: Types of Intracranial Hemorrhage

1. Extradural hemorrhage/epidural hematoma (EDH)

  • Source: Arterial - middle meningeal artery (m/c)
  • Cause: Trauma - fracture of the squamous part of the temporal bone
  • Lens or lentiform shaped opacity
  • Presence of a characteristic lucid interval
  • Treatment: Surgical evacuation of large/rapidly evolving EDH

 

2. Acute subdural hemorrhage (SDH)

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Trauma
  • Common in old age, alcoholics, patients on anticoagulants, shaken baby syndrome (a form of child abuse seen in infants and toddlers)
  • Clinical features: Acute SDH may be associated with a lucid interval; chronic SDH is associated with drowsiness, headache
  • CT findings: Crescent opacity
  • Treatment: May resolve spontaneously or require surgical drainage

 

3. Acute on chronic SDH

  • Source: Venous - bridging veins
  • Cause: Usually, trivial trauma in old age or patients on anticoagulants
  • Crescent clots
  • Presence of a history of headache, confusion, and being prone to falls

 

4. Subarachnoid hemorrhage

  • Source: Arterial
  • Causes: Trauma (most common), berry aneurysm (2nd most common)
  • M/c sites: Terminal ICA, MCA bifurcation, top of basilar artery
  • Clinical features: Characteristic thunderclap headache
  • CSF: Xanthochromia
  • Hyperdensity in the subarachnoid space
  • Treatment:  Triple H therapy (hypertension, hypervolemia, and hemodilution) to prevent vasospasm, Clipping/coiling of berry aneurysm

 

5. Intra-parenchymal hemorrhage

  • Most common type of intracranial hemorrhage
  • Cause: Hypertension (most common cause)
  • Hyperdensity within the brain parenchyma
  • Site: Putamen of the basal ganglia (most common)
  • Treatment: Correction of any identified coagulopathy by infusing prothrombin complex concentrates, FFP, or fresh platelets as required; surgical evacuation for cerebellar hematoma >3 cm in size

questions.text: Autosomal dominant polycystic kidney is associated with all except _____
questions.solution:
Hepatic periportal fibrosis is seen in ARPKD.

ARPKD

  • ARPKD (autosomal recessive polycystic kidney) has numerous small cysts that arise only from the collecting ducts and result in bilateral symmetrical enlargement of the kidneys.
  • These children have declining renal function as well as severe hypertension and hepatic periportal fibrosis with portal hypertension leading to hypersplenism and esophageal varices.
  • Infants usually die of respiratory failure rather than renal problems.

ADPKD

  • The autosomal dominant ADPKD, previously called adult PKD, has cysts arising from all areas of the nephron, which are usually larger and more variable in size than the ARPKD cysts.
  • Cysts may also be present in the liver, pancreas, and spleen, and cerebral arterial aneurysms may occur.
  • Renal cystic enlargement exerts pressure on normal parenchyma, leading to its gradual destruction and glomerulosclerosis.
  • The leading cause of death in ADPKD is cardiovascular disease, which may relate to early untreated hypertension.

questions.text: Schizophrenia is characterized by all of the following except
questions.solution:
Elation is not a symptom of schizophrenia.

Symptoms of schizophrenia can be classified as positive or negative.

  • Positive symptoms are things additional to expected behavior and include delusions, hallucinations, agitation, and talkativeness.
  • Positive symptoms respond well to most traditional and atypical antipsychotic agents.
  • Negative symptoms are things missing from expected behavior and include lack of motivation, social withdrawal, flattened affect, cognitive disturbances, poor grooming, and poor (i.e., impoverished) speech content.
  • Negative symptoms respond better to atypical than to traditional antipsychotics.

questions.text: A final-year medical student is examining a baby in the ward. As the infant is pulled to sit, he notices a head lag. By what age should this infant ideally start to hold his head steady without any bobbing motion?
questions.solution:
An infant can hold his head steady when pulled to sit, without head bobbing, by the age of 4 months.

Regarding head steadiness:

  • Up till 2 months of age, there is a significant head lag when the infant is pulled to sit.
  • At 3 months, head lag is partially compensated but still present; the infant attains early head control with bobbing motion and sits with back rounded.
  • At 4 months, there is no head lag when pulled to sit and the infant sits with full truncal support.

questions.text: A patient with a bullous disorder is referred to the dermatology OPD for further investigations. Direct immunofluorescence microscopy is performed. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows a characteristic fish-net appearance on direct immunofluorescence, which is diagnostic of pemphigus vulgaris.

This pattern is due to intraepidermal intercellular deposition of IgG and C3.

Direct or indirect immunofluorescence cannot be used to differentiate between pemphigus vulgaris and pemphigus foliaceus, as they present similarly. 

Options A and C: Bullous pemphigoid, cicatricial pemphigoid, and epidermolysis bullosa acquisita present linear or shoreline pattern is seen in due to IgG and C3 deposits along the dermo-epidermal junctions, as seen in the following image.

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis presents with focal granular deposits of IgA at papillary tips, as seen below.

questions.text: Which of the following structures is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear?
questions.solution:
The subiculum is not a part of the lateral wall of the middle ear. It is present in the medial wall, below the sinus tympani.

The lateral wall of the middle ear separates it from the external ear. It contains:

  • Pars tensa lying opposite to the mesotympanum
  • Pars flaccida and scutum lying opposite to the epitympanum.

Scutum or lateral attic wall is a wedge-shaped bone that separates the epitympanum from the external auditory canal. It can be eroded in attic cholesteatomas.

questions.text: St Antony’s fire is a term related to
questions.solution:
St Antony’s fire is a term related to ergot. Ergot is the product of a fungus Claviceps purpurea that grows on rye and other grains.

In the past, the limbs were assumed to be consumed by the holy fire resulting in blackened charcoal-like limbs with agonizing pain. The disease was called holy fire or St. Anthony’s fire in honor of the saint whose shrine offered relief to such patients.

The contamination of the edible grains with the fungus resulted in symptoms resembling ergot poisoning. Affected individuals had gangrene of feet, legs, hands, and arms. In severe cases, the extremities became dry, black and mummified limbs separated off without any loss of blood.

questions.text: How are X-rays produced?

choices.text: When electron beam strikes the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode
When electron beam reacts with the electromagnetic field
When electron beam strikes the cathode

questions.solution:
X-rays are produced when the electron beam decelerates close to the nucleus of the atom in the anode.

The production of X-rays is as follows.

Current is passed through a tungsten filament which acts as the cathode
↓
Electrons are emitted as a result of thermionic emission
↓
Electrons bombard the target anode, a tungsten disc
↓ 
Results in the conversion of energy into heat (99%) and X-ray photons(1%)

 

The target anode is made of a tungsten disc in ordinary diagnostic X-ray tubes and molybdenum in mammography X-ray tubes.

At the anode, fast-moving electrons interact with the atoms of the anode in one of the following ways:

  • Nucleus field interaction: aka continuous spectrum radiation or Bremsstrahlung reaction (80%)
  • Inner shell interaction: produces characteristic spectrum radiation (20%)

 

Important parameters with respect to X rays:

  • Kilovolt peak (kVP) – Potential difference between cathode and anode. When the voltage increases, energy increases, and penetration also increases. Hence more kVP is required for obese patients.
  • Milliampere second (mAS) – Determines the amount of film blackening. More MAS more is radiation exposure.
  • Contrast is influenced by both kVP and mAS.
  • kVP is inversely proportional whereas mAS is directly proportional to the contrast produced.

questions.text: What process is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3?

choices.text: Movement of Na+ into the cell
Movement of Na+ out of the cell
Movement of K+ into the cell
Movement of K+ out of the cell

questions.solution:
The graph depicts action potential. The movement of Na+ into the cell is responsible for the change in membrane potential that occurs between point 1 and point 3.

Once the membrane is depolarized to the threshold, local potential, the upstroke of the nerve action potential is caused by the opening of the Na+ channels. The entry of Na+ causes the opening of more voltage-gated Na+ channels and further depolarization, setting up a positive feedback loop. When the Na+ channels open, Na+ moves into the cell down its electrochemical gradient, driving the membrane potential toward the Na+ equilibrium potential.

The process responsible for repolarization is the opening of K+. The K+ permeability becomes very high and drives the membrane potential toward the K+equilibrium potential by the flow of K+ out of the cell.

questions.text: Which of the following statements about penicillin-binding proteins is false?

choices.text: Present within cell membrane of bacteria
Mutation in the PBPs gives rise to resistance
PBPs are involved in protein synthesis

questions.solution:
The targets for the action of β-lactam antibiotics are collectively termed penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs)  and they are not involved in protein synthesis.

Transpeptidase enzyme and related proteins constitute the penicillin-binding proteins (PBPs) which are present in the bacterial cell membrane. Transpepetidase is involved in the synthesis of peptidoglycan of the bacterial cell wall. All β-lactam groups of antibiotics bind to PBPs and inhibit the last step in peptidoglycan synthesis.

Mutation in the different PBPs confers resistance to the bacteria against the beta-lactams. Methicillin resistance in Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) occurs due to alteration in the PBPs.

Imipenem targets the PBPs, disrupting cell wall synthesis and causing death of the micro-organism.

Beta-lactam group of antibiotics include:

  • Penicillins
  • Cephalosporins
  • Carbapenems
  • Monobactam

questions.text: A patient is undergoing the test depicted in the image given below. Which of the following diseases does it help to diagnose?
questions.solution:
The given image depicts a string test or entero test and is used in the diagnosis of giardiasis.

It is a useful method for obtaining the duodenal specimen in giardiasis.

In this test, a coiled thread inside a small weighted gelatin capsule is swallowed by the patient, after attaching the free end of the thread in the cheek. The capsule passes through the stomach to the duodenum. After 2 hours, the thread is withdrawn, placed in saline, and is shaken. The centrifuged deposit of the saline is then examined for giardia.

questions.text: A worried mother brought her 4-year-old son to the ER with complaints of a nose bleed. On examination, the bleed was found to be from the Kiesselbach’s plexus. Which of the following arteries does not contribute to its formation?
questions.solution:
The posterior ethmoidal artery does not contribute to the formation of Kiesselbach’s plexus.

Kiesselbach’s plexus is the vascular anastomosis situated at Little’s area (anteroinferior part of the septum).

The contributing arteries are as follows:

  • Sphenopalatine and greater palatine branches of the maxillary artery, which in turn is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Septal branch of the superior labial artery which in turn is a branch of the facial artery. The facial artery is a branch of the external carotid artery.
  • Anterior ethmoidal branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery.

The posterior ethmoidal artery is a branch of the ophthalmic division of internal carotid artery, which supplies nasal septum but does not contribute to Kiesselbach’s plexus.

This question was asked in recent AIIMS and NEET examinations, making it a potential repeat.

questions.text: Neurulation refers to the process of formation of ______
questions.solution:
• Neurulation refers to the process of the formation of the Neural tube.
  • The nervous system develops from the ectoderm overlying the notochord, known as the neurectoderm.
  • The neurectoderm overlying the notochord becomes thickened to form the neural plate.
  • The neural plate is further converted to neural groove, and then to the neural tube.

There is an increased activity of uterine collagenases and release of proteolytic enzymes.

questions.text: What is the most common type of multifetal pregnancy?
questions.solution:
The most common type of multifetal pregnancy is dizygotic twinning, which is always dichorionic diamniotic. 

The incidence of dizygotic twins is 80% among twins. Of the monozygotic twins, monochorionic diamniotic is the most common (13-14%).

Zygosity refers to the type of conception while chorionicity refers to the type of placentation.

Types of twin pregnancies:

  • Dizygotic: 2 ova are fertilized by 2 sperms to form 2 separate zygotes.
  • Monozygotic: Single zygote (1 ovum fertilized by 1 sperm) divides into 2.
Feature Monozygotic Dizygotic
Phenotype Identical Non-identical
Genotype Identical Non-identical
Incidence 1:250 (constant worldwide) Varies with demography
Incidence after ART Increases Increases
Perinatal complications High Low

questions.text: A 34-year-old male patient presented to the clinic with a history of diarrhea and poor appetite. He has been having 4-5 episodes of non-bloody, loose stools per day for the last 3 months. A duodenal biopsy is taken and the histopathology is as shown below. Which of the following is the most common cancer associated with this condition?
questions.solution:
The given scenario and histopathology findings are suggestive of celiac disease. Enteropathy-associated T-cell lymphoma is the most common cancer associated with celiac disease.

Small intestinal adenocarcinoma is also associated with celiac disease.

Celiac disease or celiac sprue or gluten-sensitive enteropathy is triggered by the ingestion of gluten, which is the major storage protein of wheat and similar grains. It usually affects the 2nd part of the duodenum or proximal jejunum. 

Antibodies associated with celiac disease are: 

  • Anti-gliadin antibodies
  • Anti tissue transglutaminase antibodies
  • Anti endomysial antibodies

MARSH's score is used to assess celiac disease histologically. 

Dermatitis herpetiformis occurs in about 10% of patients with celiac disease.

questions.text: Which of the following is the earliest feature in vitamin A deficiency?

choices.text: Loss of sensitivity to green light

questions.solution:
Loss of sensitivity to green light is the earliest feature of vitamin A deficiency while nyctalopia (night blindness) is the earliest symptom of vitamin A deficiency.

Vitamin A is a fat-soluble vitamin that can occur as carotenoids (most common - beta carotene from plant sources) or retinoids (from animal sources). Dietary sources of vitamin A are liver, fish, eggs, dark green, and deeply coloured fruits and vegetables.

3 forms of retinoids are:

  • Retinal is required mainly for normal vision (present in the visual pigment rhodopsin).
  • Retinol is important for the normal functioning of the reproductive system.
  • Retinoic acid has a role in the regulation of gene expression and tissue differentiation.

The sequence of visual defects in vitamin A deficiency:

  1. Loss of sensitivity to green light
  2. Impairment of the eye to adapt to dim light
  3. Night blindness
  4. Bitot spots on the conjunctiva - white patches of keratinized epithelium on the sclera
  5. Prolonged deficiency of vitamin A → xerophthalmia (dryness of the conjunctiva and cornea)
  6. If xerophthalmia is not treated, it results in keratomalacia (softening of the cornea), corneal ulceration, corneal scarring and ultimately complete blindness.

The image below shows a Bitot's spot which is pathognomic of vitamin A deficiency.

Other manifestations of vitamin A deficiency:

  • General impairment of immunity
  • Keratinization of skin (phrynoderma/toad skin)

Related Pearl: WHO grading of Vitamin A deficiency

The term xerophthalmia is reserved to cover all the ocular manifestations of vitamin A deficiency.

Stage Features Pathophysiology
XN Night blindness Lack of rhodopsin
X1A Conjunctival Xerosis Conjunctival epithelial alteration, loss of goblet cells
X1B Bitot’s spots Conjunctival keratinization and plaque formation
X2 Corneal xerosis Corneal epithelial alteration
X3A Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting <1/3rd of the corneal surface Liquefaction of corneal stroma
X3B Corneal ulceration/ Keratomalacia affecting >1/3rd of the corneal surface              -
XS Corneal scar              -
XF Xerophthalmic fundus Degeneration of the retinal pigment epithelium

 

The first symptom of xerophthalmia is nyctalopia.

The first sign of xerophthalmia is conjunctival xerosis.

The pathognomonic feature of xerophthalmia is the appearance of Bitot's spots.

Note:

Up to Stage X2, the manifestations are reversible if treated with vitamin A supplements. Active conjunctival xerosis and Bitot’s spots begin to resolve within 2—5 days after supplementation. Most will disappear within 2 weeks, although a significant proportion of temporal lesions may persist in shrunken form and may therefore not be completely reversible.

questions.text: An elderly man with atherosclerosis presented with abdominal pain and blood-stained stools.  CECT abdomen is suggestive of ischemic colitis at the splenic flexure involving the marginal artery of Drummond. What are the arteries contributing to the formation of this structure?

choices.text: Right colic and left colic arteries
Left colic and middle colic arteries

questions.solution:
The middle and left colic arteries contribute to the formation of the marginal artery of Drummond at the splenic flexure. The splenic flexure (Griffith's point) is a watershed area of the colon which is more prone to ischemia. 

The anastomotic vessel that runs in the mesentery along the inner margin of the colon is called the marginal artery of Drummond. From this artery, numerous small branches are given to the large bowel. It is formed by:

  • Branches of superior mesenteric artery - middle colic, right colic, and ileocolic arteries
  • Branches of inferior mesenteric artery - left colic, sigmoid, and superior rectal arteries

When ischemia occurs at Griffith's point, the blood supply in this region is augmented by another arterial loop called the inner arterial arc (of Riolan). This arc connects the main trunk of the middle colic artery with the ascending branch of the left colic artery.

Note: Sudeck's point is another watershed area present at the rectosigmoid junction. The sigmoid artery anastomoses with the superior rectal artery at this site.

questions.text: A mother brought her 15-year-old daughter to the OPD with concerns of excessive growth of coarse hair over her face and chest. Which scoring system is used to clinically grade this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of hirsutism. The Ferriman-Gallwey score is used to clinically assess and quantify the degree of hirsutism.

Within this system, abnormal hair distribution is assessed at nine body areas and each of them scored from 0-4. Increasing numeric scores correspond to greater hair density within a given area. The maximum score is 36. The degree of hirsutism is mild if the score is ≥8. Moderate to severe hirsutism is present if the score is ≥15.

Note: Ferriman Gallwey score originally had 11 sites which were modified later to exclude 2 sites, viz., forearm, and legs.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the condition seen in the image given below?

choices.text: Flattening of tubal plicae is seen on histology
Its ampullary region is filled with clear fluid

questions.solution:
The above image depicts a hydrosalpinx. Its wall is not opaque but translucent.

If a pyosalpinx responds to antibiotics, the pus present inside becomes sterile within 6 weeks of the initial attack. However, the damage to the tube remains as chronic pyosalpinx or hydrosalpinx. A hydrosalpinx represents the end result of previous acute salpingitis and is often bilateral.

The tube becomes retort shaped due to the enormous dilatation of the ampullary region that is filled with clear fluid.

Histological examination shows a flattening of the tubal plicae and exfoliation of the lining epithelium.

questions.text:
A 35-year-man presents with nosebleeds, bleeding gums, and multiple ecchymoses. Lab investigations show the following findings. The blasts are positive for CD33. What is the most likely diagnosis?

Hb: 8.5 g/dL

Platelet count: 12,000/Cumm

TLC: 52,000/Cumm with 83% blasts
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of acute myeloid leukemia (AML).

AML is a tumor of hematopoietic progenitors caused by acquired oncogenic mutations that impede differentiation, leading to the accumulation of immature myeloid blasts in the marrow. It occurs at all ages, but the incidence rises throughout life, peaking after 60 years of age. 

The peripheral smear shows blasts with abundant cytoplasm, fine azurophilic granules, Auer rods, and delicate nuclear chromatin with 1-4 prominent nucleoli. The blasts are positive for CD33. Occasionally, blasts are entirely absent from the blood (aleukemic leukemia). Bone marrow examination is essential to exclude acute leukemia in pancytopenic patients.

 

Related Pearl: WHO classification of Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)

The 5th edition of WHO (2022) classification classifies acute myeloid leukemia (AML) as follows:

AML with defining genetic abnormalities (gene or chromosome changes):

  • Acute promyelocytic leukemia with PML::RARA fusion
  • AML with RUNX1::RUNX1T1 fusion
  • AML with CBFB::MYH11 fusion
  • AML with DEK::NUP214 fusion
  • AML with RBM15::MRTFA fusion
  • AML with BCR::ABL1 fusion
  • AML with KMT2A rearrangement*
  • AML with MECOM rearrangement
  • AML with NUP98 rearrangement
  • AML with NPM1 mutation
  • AML with CEBPA mutation
  • AML, myelodysplasia-related#
  • AML with other defined genetic alterations

 AML, defined by differentiation:

  • AML with minimal differentiation
  • AML without maturation
  • AML with maturation
  • Acute basophilic leukaemia
  • Acute myelomonocytic leukaemia
  • Acute monocytic leukaemia
  • Acute erythroid leukaemia
  • Acute megakaryoblastic leukemia

Most AML with defining genetic abnormalities are diagnosed with < 20% blasts except AML with BCR: ABL1 and AML with CEBPA mutation that require at least 20% blasts for diagnosis.

*AML with KMT2A rearrangement is the new term that replaces “AML with t(9;11)(p22;q23); KMT2A-MLLT3

#AML with myelodysplasia-related changes has been renamed as AML, myelodysplasia-related (AML-MR).

questions.text: A 65-year-old hypertensive patient presents with chest pain and dyspnea following an alcohol binge. His ECG is shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The ECG shows narrow QRS complexes with irregular RR intervals and no distinct P waves. This is suggestive of atrial fibrillation.

Atrial fibrillation (AF) is a supraventricular tachycardia caused by ectopic foci or small reentry circuits within the atria. It has an atrial rate of 400-600/min and a ventricular rate of 100-160/min. 

Risk factors for developing AF include:

  • Age- usually above 60 years of age
  • Underlying heart disease
  • Hypertension
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Obesity
  • Sleep apnea
  • Post-cardiac surgery
  • Inflammatory pericarditis

Acute precipitating factors for AF include:

  • Hyperthyroidism
  • Acute alcohol intoxication
  • Acute illness like myocardial infarction and pulmonary embolism

questions.text: The coronal suture present between the frontal and parietal bones descends down until it reaches ______
questions.solution:
• The coronal suture is present between the posterior margin of the frontal bone and the anterior margins of the two parietal bones.
  • It descends down until it meets the junction between the greater wing of the sphenoid and the squamous temporal bone at the pterion.

Pterion:

  • All four bones of one side (Frontal, Parietal, Temporal, and Sphenoid) meet at a roughly H-shaped sutural junction termed the pterion.
  • This is an important landmark as it overlies both the anterior branch of the middle meningeal artery and the lateral fissure of the cerebral hemisphere.
  • The pterion corresponds to the site of the anterolateral (sphenoidal) fontanelle of the neonatal skull, which closes in the sixth month after birth. 

The bregma is present the junction of the frontal bone and two parietal bones. It represents the site of the anterior fontanelle in a young child. 

The lambda is present at the junction of right and left parietal bones and the occipital bone. The lambdoid suture delineates the articulation between the posterior borders of the right and left parietal bones and the superior border of the occipital bone.

questions.text: A patient with salicylic acid poisoning has the following arterial blood gas analysis report: pH = 7.1, pCO2 =18mmHg, HCO3-=12mmol/L. Identify the acid-base disorder here.

choices.text: Respiratory acidosis with compensatory metabolic alkalosis
Metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis

questions.solution:
The acid-base disorder here is a mixed disorder of metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

It should not be confused with metabolic acidosis with uncompensated respiratory alkalosis. This can be understood by the following calculation:

Step 1: The pH in this patient is 7.1 (pH <7.35) which indicates acidosis

Step 2: HCO3- is 12 mmol/L (Normal HCO3- - 22–30 mmol/L). In metabolic acidosis, HCO3- levels decrease.

Hence, this is a case of metabolic acidosis.

Step 3: As per Winter's formula, the expected respiratory compensation in metabolic acidosis can be calculated using,

      pCO2 =( 1.5 x [HCO3-] ) +8 ± 2

In this case, Expected pCO2 = ( 1.5 x [12] ) +8 ± 2

                                          = 26 ± 2

                                          = 24 - 28 mmHg

The pCO2 in this patient is 18 mmHg, which implies there is an overcompensation of pCO2. This overcompensation can happen only if there is an additional component of respiratory alkalosis contributing to reduced pCO2.

Hence, this patient has a mixed disorder - metabolic acidosis and respiratory alkalosis. 

Related Pearl: Interpretation of Acid-Base Disorders

pH<7.35 is acidosis

pH>7.45 is alkalosis

A primary change in HCO3- is termed metabolic

If the change in HCO3- is in keeping with the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and HCO3- is decreased) the problem is metabolic.

If the change in HCO3- is opposite with the pH (i.e. if there is acidosis and HCO3- is increased or normal) the problem is compensatory metabolic.

A primary change in CO2 is termed as respiratory

If the change in CO2 keeping in line with the pH (if in acidosis CO2 is raised) the problem is termed respiratory

If the change in CO2 is in the opposite direction of that of the pH (i.e. if there are acidosis and CO2 is decreased or normal ) the problem is termed compensatory respiratory

questions.text: Which of the following is affected in patients with Weber-Osler-Rendu syndrome?
questions.solution:
Weber–Osler–Rendu syndrome is a disorder of the blood vessels.

It is an autosomal-dominant disorder caused by mutations that modulate TGF-β signalling. It is also known as hereditary hemorrhagic telangiectasia. 

This condition is characterized by dilated, tortuous blood vessels with thin walls that bleed readily. Bleeding is most common in the mucous membranes of the nose (epistaxis), tongue, mouth, and eyes, and throughout the gastrointestinal tract.

Platelet count, prothrombin time (PT), and activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT) are normal.

Clinical conditions in which abnormalities of vessel wall cause bleeding include:

  • Infections - meningococcemia, infective endocarditis, rickettsioses
  • Collagen defects - Ehlers–Danlos syndrome, scurvy, and Cushing's syndrome
  • Perivascular amyloidosis - most common with amyloid light-chain (AL) amyloidosis
  • Henoch–Schönlein purpura
  • Drug reactions

questions.text: On your pediatrics rotation, you notice a 2-day-old baby with the rash shown in the image below. Which among the following is the most likely cause for this baby's rash?
questions.solution:
The image shows purple papulonodular lesions, which are suggestive of blueberry muffin rash. It is seen in congenital rubella.

Blueberry muffin rash represents dermal erythropoiesis. In addition to congenital rubella, it can be seen in: 

  • Congenital viral infections such as cytomegalovirus and parvovirus
  • Neoplasms such as neuroblastoma and acute myeloid leukemia
  • Rh hemolytic disease

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false regarding medico-legal autopsy?

choices.text: Magistrate is the authorizing officer in case of exhumation
In India, all registered medical practitioners can perform an autopsy

questions.solution:
In the case of a medicolegal autopsy, consent of the relatives is not required.

For conducting a medicolegal autopsy:

  • Legal authorization is a must
  • Magistrate is the authorizing officer in case of exhumation
  • Preferably, a forensic pathologist or medicolegal expert does the autopsy. However, in India, due to the lack of adequate qualified experts, all registered medical practitioners can perform this with authorization by the state.

Note: Clinical/ pathological autopsy requires consent from the relatives of the deceased.

questions.text: A software engineer presented with complaints of dryness and itching of eyes on staring at his laptop screen. On examination, parotid swelling was noted and the test shown below was positive. The serology of this patient is likely to be positive for which of the following antibodies?
questions.solution:
The given scenario of dry eyes, parotid swelling, and a positive Schirmer test is suggestive of Sjögren's syndrome. It is associated with anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B autoantibodies.

The presence of anti-Ro/SS-A and anti-La/SS-B indicate extra glandular involvement and poor prognosis.

Note: Anti-Ro and anti-La in SLE indicate a good prognosis, due to decreased risk of nephritis and vasculitis.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would you not expect to see in a patient with Wolfram syndrome?
questions.solution:
Diabetes insipidus is a clinical component of Wolfram syndrome, and not SIADH. 

Characteristics of Wolfram syndrome include:

  • Diabetes insipidus
  • Diabetes mellitus
  • Optic atrophy
  • Sensorineural deafness

(Mnemonic DIDMOAD)

Wolfram syndrome is caused by mutations of the WFS1 gene.

questions.text: Which of the following is not stated in the definition of sanitation by the National Sanitation Foundation of USA?
questions.solution:
According to the National Sanitation Foundation (NSF) of USA, sanitation is defined as the quality of living that is expressed in the clean home, the clean farm, the clean business, the clean neighborhood, and the clean community.

The WHO defines environmental sanitation as the control of all those factors in man’s physical environment which exercise or may exercise a deleterious effect on his physical development, health, and survival.

In recent times, the term environmental sanitation has been replaced by environmental health.

questions.text: Which of the following features would you not expect to see in a patient with Guillian-Barre syndrome?
questions.solution:
Bladder dysfunction is not usually severe and does not appear early in the course of Guillain-Barre Syndrome(GBS). If bladder dysfunction is a prominent feature and comes early in the course, diagnostic possibilities other than GBS should be considered.

GBS is an acute demyelinating polyradiculoneuropathy. It is an autoimmune disorder triggered by infections like:

  • Campylobacter jejuni 
  • Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
  • Epstein Barr virus
  • Mycoplasma
  • Varicella zoster virus
  • Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV), dengue, or influenza

It manifests as a rapidly evolving areflexic motor paralysis, with or without sensory disturbance. The usual pattern is ascending paralysis. Proximal and distal muscles are equally involved. The lower cranial nerves are frequently affected, causing bulbar weakness.

questions.text: Nikshay is a surveillance system used in the national programme for which disease?
questions.solution:
• Nikshay is a web based IT system for case-based tuberculosis surveillance under the RNTCP. 
  • This system stores information about the patient, medical history, diagnosis, co-morbidities and lab reports.

questions.text: A patient presents with a wound on his leg with purulent discharge. Pus culture was positive for MRSA. Which of the following drugs will you prescribe?
questions.solution:
Delafloxacin is a newer fluoroquinolone approved for use in acute bacterial skin and skin structural infections (ABSSSI) caused by susceptible bacteria including MRSA.

Compared to other fluoroquinolones which are zwitterionic in nature, delafloxacin is anionic. This enables the molecule to achieve increased intracellular penetration and concentration, especially under acidic conditions (skin wounds). This results in increased antimicrobial activity and a decreased adverse event profile at clinically potent doses.
